I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2009  country  programming  mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) for the Study on Beijing Green Finance Development Strategy. A fact-finding 
mission  visited  Beijing  on  20–27  April  2010,  and  an  understanding  was  reached  on  the 
objectives,  scope,  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation 
arrangements of the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The PRC is the largest carbon dioxide emitting country in the world and has made 
commitments to reduce its emissions per unit of gross domestic product by 40%–45% of 2005 
levels by 2020. Addressing this issue is a priority for the government, but reducing emissions 
needs to be balanced with the requirements of economic development. Development of green 
finance is one of the ways the government is exploring to achieve this balance.    
 
3.  Green finance  consists of financial activities  (such  as investments, capital  markets, 
venture capital, insurance, guarantees, asset management, banking, and lending) that support 
environmentally  focused  activities  and  industries.  Carbon  finance  is  one  of  the  largest 
components of green finance  and  developing  this sector  will  have  a  major impact  on  the 
reduction of carbon emissions. 
 
4.  Beijing  municipal  government  has  an  ambitious  strategy  to  position  Beijing  as  an 
international financial center for green finance, spearheaded by the successful development of 
carbon finance. International climate change engagements are driven by the government in 
Beijing; Beijing has the additional advantage of being one of the PRC’s major financial centers. 
Hence, locating the green finance center in the political center of the PRC will foster synergies 
and interaction between the private sector and the government to encourage rapid progress in 
the green finance sector. 
 
5.  Beijing municipal government proposes the development of the Beijing  pilot carbon 
finance district (CFD), which will be a hub for carbon finance and green finance transactions in 
the PRC. The pilot CFD is to be located in  Beijing’s Dongcheng district, which has been 
designated a low-carbon economic zone. The plan also calls for the expansion of the China 
Beijing Environment Exchange (CBEEX) into a major exchange for carbon finance products. 
The creation of the pilot CFD and a major exchange will promote the growth of environmental 
finance business. Increased financial transactions and innovations, in turn, will finance activities 
that will lead to reduced greenhouse gas emissions.  
 
6.  The  TA  will  help  the  PRC  achieve  its  emissions  reduction  target  through  the 
development of carbon finance. It will conduct a study on the state of carbon finance in the PRC, 
make recommendations on enabling policies, and create a road map for the establishment of 
the carbon finance center in Beijing. The results of the TA will form the basis for discussions and 
policy recommendations to relevant government agencies, such as the National Development 
and Reform Commission, China Banking Regulatory Commission, China Securities Regulatory 
Commission, People’s Bank of China, and the Ministry of Finance. 
 
                                                 
1   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 23 April 2010.

2 
7.  The PRC country partnership strategy, 2008–2010 identified resource efficiency and 
environment sustainability as one of four main thrusts, as energy efficiency and emissions 
reduction  are  important  measures  that  lead  to  the  achievement  of  sustainable  economic 
growth.2 The TA will play an important role in the achievement of the CPS goals. ADB is ideally 
positioned to provide the TA since it has been working with stakeholders in the PRC to address 
policy and financial market issues related to carbon finance and environmental finance. In 
addition, its experience with climate change, carbon funds, as well as the Carbon Market 
Initiative, will be instrumental for the smooth execution of the TA. 
 
8.  Risks include (i) the government changing its commitment to emissions reduction, (ii) the 
market and participants not having enough capacity to adopt the sophisticated instruments and 
manage related risks, and (iii) the government not supporting the plan for carbon finance and 
the establishment of the pilot CFD. 
 
9.  Currently, three environmental exchanges have been set up as pilot schemes—one 
each in Beijing, Shanghai, and Tianjin—to explore the feasibility of emissions trading. The 
CBEEX  was  founded  on  5  August  2008  by  China  Beijing  Equity  Exchange,  New  Energy 
Investment of China National Offshore Oil Corporation, China Guodian Corporation, and China 
Everbright Investment Management. It was established with the approval of Beijing municipal 
government. The CBEEX, together with BlueNext (Europe’s largest carbon credits exchange) 
and the China Forestry Exchange, recently released the first standard for voluntary greenhouse 
gas offset entitled Panda Standard Version 1.0. The standard for carbon projects aims to 
provide transparency and credibility to the nascent domestic voluntary carbon market. However, 
the  concept  of  emissions  trading  is  relatively  new  and  enabling  policies,  regulations,  and 
legislation need to be developed.    
 
10.  ADB is working with the CBEEX to develop the PRC’s first voluntary emissions reduction 
standard, to ensure standard quality for voluntary emissions reduction and trading.3 ADB is 
providing  TA  focusing  on  project  design  document  development,  validation,  registration, 
verification, and credit issuance. The proposed TA will coordinate efforts to minimize overlap 
and repetition, and encourage cooperation among TA teams. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact of the TA will be its contribution to the establishment of the Beijing pilot CFD 
and the development of the CBEEX as a major carbon market in the PRC. Success will be 
measured by the doubling the trading volume in the CBEEX by 2015 as compared to the 2010 
volume. The outcome will be a detailed road map for development of the carbon market in the 
PRC and the establishment of the Beijing pilot CFD. The road map will be proposed to key 
government agencies, such as the Ministry of Finance and the National Development and 
Reform Commission. Should the proposals be adopted and implemented, the creation of an 
efficient and transparent marketplace for emissions trading and carbon finance in the PRC will 
spur the transition to a low-carbon economy. This will aid in enabling the PRC to achieve its 
emissions reduction goals.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will ascertain the state of carbon finance in the PRC and identify potential areas 
of development. It will then focus on preparing the road map and strategy for the development 
of Beijing into an international center of carbon trading and green finance. One of the TA 
outputs will be policy recommendations to attract and promote the growth of carbon and green 
finance-related enterprises into the pilot CFD in Beijing. The TA will also address the strategy 
for the CBEEX to transform into a major carbon trading exchange. 
 
13.  The TA will conduct the following activities: 
(i)  Identify key issues in the development of a carbon market in the PRC, establish the 
Beijing pilot CFD, and formulate a strategy for the CBEEX, preparing three technical 
reports on: 
(a) the current state and potential development of the carbon market in the PRC, 
focusing on (1) the preparation of an actionable national strategy and road map 
for the  development  of the voluntary  emissions reduction  market,  and the 
transition of the carbon market from being project-based to being commodity-
based and finally to being financial market-based, (2) the state of the Clean 
Development Mechanism market, (3) the development of a joint plan by the 
government and private enterprise market to manage the PRC’s carbon assets, 
and (4) the formulation of policy recommendations to support the growth of a 
carbon market in the PRC; 
(b) the  development  strategy  for  the  Beijing  pilot  CFD,  focusing  on  (1)  the 
assessment of the state of the finance business sector, (2) a comparative 
analysis of Beijing and other global finance centers, (3) an actionable road map 
for the Beijing pilot CFD in the Dongcheng district, and (4) recommendations to 
Beijing municipal government on business-friendly policies to attract relevant 
ventures; 
(c) strategic  development  of  the  CBEEX,  including  (1)  a  5-year  plan  for  the 
CBEEX; (2) the design of the voluntary emissions reduction electronic trading 
platform and trading regulations; (3) the design of trading products, instruments, 
and  pricing  mechanisms;  and  (4)  a  plan  for  cultivating  carbon  market 
participants through trade associations and research institutes. 
(ii)  Based on the technical reports, develop recommendations and create knowledge 
products in the form of actionable development road map, strategy and policy and 
technical  notes  to  the  Beijing  Municipal  Bureau  of  Financial  Work.  The  Beijing 
Municipal Bureau of Financial Work will use these recommendations and knowledge 
products to promote the establishment of the pilot CFD to the Beijing municipal 
government and other policy makers. 
(iii) Develop key stakeholder understanding of the importance of the carbon market in 
the PRC and establishing the carbon trading center and the CFD through six to eight 
forums and workshops. The TA will conduct 
(a) forums to disseminate the results of the studies and the road map; and 
(b) workshops targeted at relevant government agencies, financial institutions, and 
stakeholders to raise awareness and influence relevant financial policy making 
and  supervisory  personnel  to  (1)  promote  the  establishment  of  a  carbon

(iv) Arrange for relevant government personnel to participate in international study tours 
and make  on-site investigations  of overseas carbon markets. These  events  will 
provide invaluable insights on efforts to establish the CFD. These tours will allow the 
stakeholders to research and investigate the main carbon markets and exchanges in 
Asia, Australia, Europe, and the United States to study the platforms, products, 
contracts, and innovative financial tools of international carbon trade. Given the 
importance of these tours to the executing agency and implementing agency, they 
will be funded entirely through counterpart financing for the TA. Results and key 
information  obtained  from  the  study  tours  will  be  presented  and  reported  at 
workshops organized by the TA.   
 
14.  Targeted workshops and/or seminars will be organized for different stakeholders at 
various stages of project implementation. Materials from such events may be published, if 
warranted and appropriate, and used for knowledge product dissemination. Seminars will also 
be held for government officials and private sector stakeholders in relevant fields to gather their 
inputs for the reports.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $950,000 equivalent. The government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will finance 
the balance of the cost equivalent to $450,000 through provision of office space, counterpart 
staff,  project  support,  funding  for  international  study  tours,  and  workshops.  Detailed  cost 
estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Beijing Municipal Bureau of Financial Work will be the executing agency and the 
CBEEX  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  The  executing  agency  is  a  municipal  agency 
responsible for the development and promotion of the financial service industry in Beijing. Close 
collaboration  will  be  needed  among  the  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency.  The 
executing  agency  and/or  implementing  agency  will  provide  the  necessary  office  space, 
counterpart staff, and other services to the consultants; and will arrange meetings for the 
consultants with relevant agencies and organizations.  
 
17.  The TA is included in the list of delegated TA projects for 2010. The fact-finding mission 
conducted an assessment of technical ability to implement the TA. The capacity assessment 
was conducted jointly with the Central Operations Services Office to determine the executing 
and implementing agencies capacity to implement TA in the areas of (i) human and physical 
resources,  (ii)  agency  procurement  processes,  (iii)  process  control  and  oversight,  and  (iv) 
records keeping. The assessment concluded that, while capacity was satisfactory, given that 
this is the first TA that will be undertaken by both agencies, it is recommended that EAFM with 
the  support  of  COSO  would  provide  substantial  support  and  guidance  throughout  the 
implementation process.  It is recommended that the TA be delegated to the executing and 
implementing  agencies  based  on  the  ―enhanced  partnership‖  approach  detailed  in  the 
memorandum of understanding recently concluded between ADB and the Ministry of Finance. 
The process and responsibilities of the parties in recruiting consultants under the ―enhanced 
partnership‖ approach is outlined in Appendix 3.

5 
18.  The  TA  will  engage  a  team  of  consultants  with  expertise  in  carbon  finance, 
environmental law, and exchange establishment and operations. Three international consultants 
(total of 8 person-months) and four national consultants (total of 17 person-months) will be 
engaged. The table on allocation of consulting services provides a breakdown by expertise. 
Appendix 4 provides the outline terms of reference for the consultants. The international and 
national consultants will be selected and engaged either individually or through a firm. If a firm is 
to be used, the preferred selection method for consultants is quality- and cost-based selection 
with a quality–cost ratio of 80:20. Consultant engagement will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of 
the TA will be disbursed in line with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). If equipment is to be purchased for use during the TA, it will be 
in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and 
will be turned over to the executing agency on completion of the TA. For equipment, training 
seminars, and conferences, an advance payment facility could be used.

19.  The TA is expected to be effective in September 2010 and end in September 2012. The 
consultants will submit to both ADB and the executing agency and the implementing agency (i) 
the inception report 2 weeks after commencement of services, (ii) interim progress reports at 
appropriate stages during TA implementation, (iii) draft final reports before the conclusion of the 
contract, and (iv) the final report 2 weeks after receiving comments from the executing agency 
and implementing agency and ADB. All reports must be submitted in English and Chinese. 
Workshops will be organized periodically for the dissemination of the consultants’ findings and 
the discussion of policy recommendations. 
 
20.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored and reported on by the executing 
agency  or  implementing  agency  and  ADB  review  missions.  Consultants’  reports  will  be 
presented at workshops and seminars organized for the validation of findings. Reports will be 
made available on ADB websites in English and Chinese and published, in accordance with 
ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005, as amended from time to time).  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 financed on a grant 
basis for the Study on Beijing Green Finance Development Strategy, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Appendix 4  11 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  International  consultants  will  be  primarily  responsible  for  introducing  international 
experience and best practice, providing advisory services and acting as peer reviewer for 
research reports on technical issues, disseminating lessons, and providing recommendations to 
policy makers. International consultants will also review reports that have been translated from 
Chinese  to  English  to  ensure  that  technical  issues  are  addressed  accurately.  National 
consultants will work with international consultants to adapt international best practice to the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC), prepare research reports and recommendations, and be 
responsible for the technical aspects of implementing the technical assistance (TA) project. 
 
2.  The consultants will be responsible for producing TA outputs and deliverables effectively 
and on time, and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities. The consultants will produce 
the following deliverables: (i) technical reports, in both English and Chinese (as appropriate), on 
carbon market and policy recommendations for the PRC, a road map for the development of the 
pilot  carbon  finance  district  (CFD),  and  strategic  development  plans  for  the  China  Beijing 
Environment Exchange (CBEEX); (ii) the policy note for decision makers; and (iii) participation 
in forums and workshops to  disseminate research results and to promote carbon finance. 
Where possible, consultants should build on existing bodies of research and coordinate with 
government stakeholders on TA activities. 
 
A.  International Consultants (8 person-months) 
 
3.  Carbon finance expert (3 person-months, intermittent). The consultant should have 
expert knowledge and sufficient experience in areas related to international carbon finance 
instruments and transactions, and the physical and electronic infrastructure of global carbon 
exchanges and markets. The consultant will  
(i)  utilize  his  knowledge  of  the  international  carbon  market  and  instruments  to 
provide guidance on the framework for the development  of transactions and 
trading platforms of the Beijing CFD; 
(ii)  work with the CBEEX and national consultants in the design and development of 
carbon instrument products; 
(iii)  recommend  guidelines  and  standard  practice  incorporating  international  best 
practice into the domestic market; 
(iv)  work closely with private sector financial institutions to ensure their participation 
and buy-in on the project; 
(v)  contribute to, and prepare, the technical reports on carbon market and policy 
recommendations for the PRC, a road map for the development of the pilot CFD, 
and strategic development plans for the CBEEX; 
(vi)  work with the executing agency, implementing agency and national consultants 
in identifying key issues to be covered in workshops and seminars, preparing 
background materials, and choosing resource persons; and 
(vii)  deliver  sessions  on  international  practice  and  experiences  during  training 
workshops.

consultant  should  have  expert  knowledge  and  experience  in  the  latest  international

consultant will

related to environmental finance and the PRC’s carbon finance market; 
(ii)  monitor relevant regulatory developments in carbon finance and carbon market

(iii)  provide guidance on the government supervisory framework, laws, and policies

(iv)  provide advice and recommendations on global standards on the legal aspects of

(v)  prepare the technical reports on carbon market and policy recommendations for

(vi)  advise on contracts and documents for carbon finance instruments; and

5.  Exchange establishment and operation expert (3 person-months, intermittent). The 
consultant should have expert knowledge and experience in the operations of trading systems 
of international environmental and carbon exchanges. The consultant will  
(i)  provide high quality inputs to the reports for the establishment and operations of 
the climate and carbon exchanges in Beijing; 
(ii)  draw on knowledge of the operations of international climate exchanges and 
provide technical guidance on building trading systems, platforms, regulations, 
supervision, compliance, transaction procedures, settlement, and middle- and 
back-office operations; 
(iii)  design the trading system to be scalable and compatible with other national and, 
potentially, regional exchanges; 
(iv)  provide key contribution to the design of the road map for the establishment of 
the CFD and development plan of the CBEEX; 
(v)  coordinate  with  financial  institutions,  international  exchanges,  and  other 
stakeholders to initiate information sharing; 
(vi)  provide contacts and coordinate with international climate exchanges  for the 
international study tours and seminars; and 
(vii)  deliver  sessions  on  international  practice  and  experiences  during  training 
workshops. 
 
B.  National Consultants (17 person-months) 
 
6.  Carbon market expert  (6 person-months, intermittent). The consultant should have 
good knowledge and sufficient professional experience in the latest international and national 
environmental finance policies, the global carbon market, and the development of voluntary 
carbon emissions reduction. The consultant will  
(i)  be responsible for the overall management of implementation of the TA, liaising 
with ADB and other related agencies, the timely delivery of good quality interim 
and final reports, identification and management of resource persons in various 
technical tasks, and organizing workshops and training activities; 
(ii)  formulate a detailed work plan for various sub-tasks, provide guidance to other 
consultants in carrying out their respective tasks, supervise the implementation of 
the  whole  TA  project,  and  ensure  the  high  quality  completion  of  various 
components; 
(iii)  evaluate intermediate and final outputs from various consultants, and on behalf 
of the consulting team, prepare interim and final TA reports;

(i)  work  with  the  international  consultant  to  provide  guidance  on  the  domestic

PRC market; 
(ii)  adapt international knowledge of the carbon finance market and tailor it to local 
markets, investors, and the legal framework; 
(iii)  provide domestic market intelligence to international consultants, facilitating more 
effective financial technology transfer; 
(iv)  work closely with private sector financial institutions to ensure their participation 
and buy-in on the project; 
(v)  prepare the technical reports on carbon market and policy recommendations for 
the  PRC,  a  road  map  for  development  of  the  pilot  CFD,  and  strategic 
development plans for the CBEEX;  
(vi)  assist the executing agency, implementing agency and international consultants 
in identifying key issues to be covered in workshops and seminars, preparing 
background materials, and choosing resource persons; and 
(vii)  participate in, and deliver, sessions during training workshops.

(ii)  work with the international consultants to provide PRC expertise and help adapt

(iii)  adapt  international  best  practice  on  exchange  governance  and  make

(iv)  monitor relevant regulatory developments in carbon finance and carbon market

suggestions for carbon finance market in the PRC; 
(vi)  develop and propose the oversight framework, laws, and policy suggestions for 
the Beijing CFD;

9.  Financial expert (3 person-months, intermittent). The consultant should have expert 
knowledge and experience in the latest financial market transactions and financial institutions. 
The consultant will  
(i)  assess the state of Beijing’s finance sector, and the trends in, and potential 
development of, new financial markets, especially in carbon finance;  
(ii)  be responsible for the business development work and strategy for the road map

(iii)  develop policies that will promote the pilot CFD to businesses and encourage the

products such as carbon credit linked credit cards; and 
(vi)  work with exchange experts to provide knowledge of traditional commodity future 
markets to design trading.
